medicine_use: Severe anxiety over a short time, Epilepsy (fits) over a longer time, Mental illness such as schizophrenia (in combination with other treatments)
common_side_effects: Problems walking or other movement problems
Reacting to things more slowly than usual
Eye problems such as double vision and rapid uncontrollable movement of the eyes
Difficulty in staying awake or alert
severe_side_effects: Believing things which are not true (delusions)
Sensing things which are not there (hallucinations)
Increased possibility of tripping or falling especially in elderly patients
Blistering or bleeding of the skin around the lips, eyes, mouth, nose and genitals
immediate_attention_side_effects: Drowsiness, difficulties breathing, coma and death may occur if Frisium is taken together with opioids
how_to_use: Always take Frisium exactly as your doctor has told you. Swallow the tablets whole, or crushed and mixed with apple sauce. The tablets can be divided into equal halves of 5mg. Frisium can be taken with or without food.
storage_instructions: Keep out of the sight and reach of children. Do not store above 25°C. Do not take Frisium after the expiry date which is stated on the label.
mechanism_of_action: Frisium works by having a calming effect on the brain.
warnings_precautions: Alcohol should not be taken during treatment with Frisium as there is an increased risk of experiencing side effects.
Patients over 65 may experience increased sensitivity to adverse reactions such as drowsiness, dizziness, and muscle weakness.
Talk to your doctor if you have kidney problems, difficulty digesting medicines, or a history of drug or alcohol dependence.
drug_interactions: Frisium can affect the way some other medicines work and vice versa. Notable interactions include antiepileptic drugs, antipsychotics, painkillers, and antidepressants.
contraindications: Allergy to clobazam or other benzodiazepines
Patients in the first three months of pregnancy
History of drug or alcohol dependence
pregnancy_lactation: Do not take Frisium if you are in the first three months of pregnancy or breastfeeding.
special_populations_children: The usual dose for children (6 years and above) is 5 mg each day.
special_populations_elderly: The usual dose for elderly patients for anxiety is 10 mg to 20 mg each day.
overdose_information: If you take more Frisium than you should, tell your doctor or go to your nearest hospital straight away.
